# This template defaults to vertical

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="70%"}

See docs on the [quarto website](https://quarto.org/docs/presentations/revealjs/advanced.html#vertical-slides)

- Use level 1 headings to go across

- Use level 2 headings to go up/down.

We use some weirdness to make this work for us.

:::

:::

## GPCDS slide styles {.story-slide}

Notice how everything looks a little different? Well, there are these special classes:

- .graph-slide
- .graph-title-slide
- .plot-slide
- .plot-title-slide
- .chart-slide
- .chart-title-slide
- .story-slide
- .story-title-slide

# Default section break

Notice there is no arrow here.

The arrow was added using 

```{verbatim}
::: {.section-arrow}
<i class="fa-solid fa-arrow-down"></i>
:::
```


# Another nice section break {.story-title-slide}

# 

### 1-3, miss the 2

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="70%"}

Using this pattern creates across slides that feel like normal progression.

```{verbatim}
#

### 1-3, miss the 2
```

However it is recommended to **AVOID THIS** as it has very non-standard behaviour. Check the source to see terrifying things done to the `<section>` tags.

:::

::: {.column width="30%"}

<span style='color:{{<brand color story-primary>}};font-size:10rem'><i class="fa-solid fa-bomb"></i></span>

:::
